revisions.rev:
{{Infobox computer underground |group_name = Goatse Security |image = Goatse Security Logo.png |image size = |caption = Goatse Security logo |other_names = GoatSec |origin = |country = |years_active = 2009—ongoing |category = [[Hacker (computer security)|Hacking]] |platforms = |founders = |members = [[weev]]
[[Sam Hocevar]]
Daniel Spitler
Leon Kaiser |products = Clench |affiliates = [[Gay Nigger Association of America]] (GNAA) |website = http://security.goatse.fr/ }} {{Portal box|Computer security|Internet}} '''Goatse Security''' ('''GoatSec''') is a loose-knit, nine-person [[grey hat]] [[hacker group]] that specializes in uncovering security flaws. It is a division of the anti-blogging [[Troll (Internet)|Internet trolling]] organization known as the [[Gay Nigger Association of America]] (GNAA). The group derives its name from the [[Goatse.cx]] [[shock site]], and it chose "Gaping Holes Exposed" as its [[slogan]]. In June 2010, Goatse Security obtained the [[Email addresses]] of approximately 114,000 Apple iPad users. This led to an [[FBI]] investigation and the filing of criminal charges against two of the group's members. ==Founding== The GNAA had several security researchers within its membership. According to Goatse Security spokesperson Leon Kaiser, the GNAA could not fully utilize their talents since the group believed that there would not be anyone who would take security data published by the GNAA seriously. In order to create a medium through which GNAA members can publish their security findings, the GNAA created Goatse Security in December 2009. ==Browser vulnerabilities== In order to protect its web browser from [[inter-protocol exploitation]], [[Mozilla]] blocked several [[Port number|ports]] that [[HTML forms]] would not normally have access to. In January 2010, the GNAA discovered that Mozilla's blocks did not cover [[6667|port 6667]], which left Mozilla browsers vulnerable to cross-protocol scripts. The GNAA crafted a [[JavaScript]]-based [[Exploit (computer security)|exploit]] in order to [[Internet Relay Chat flood|flood]] [[IRC]] channels. Although [[EFnet]] and [[OFTC]] were able to block the attacks, [[Freenode]] struggled to counteract the attacks. Goatse Security exposed the vulnerability, and one of its members, Andrew Auernheimer, aka "[[weev]]," posted information about the exploit on [[Encyclopedia Dramatica]]. In March 2010, Goatse Security discovered an [[integer overflow]] vulnerability within the [[Safari (web browser)|Apple Safari]] and posted an exploit on Encyclopedia Dramatica. They found out that a person could access a blocked port by adding 65,536 to the port number. This vulnerability was also found in [[Arora (browser)|Arora]], [[iCab]], [[OmniWeb]], and Stainless. Although Apple fixed the glitch for desktop versions of Safari in March, the company left the glitch unfixed in mobile versions of the browser. Goatse Security claimed that a hacker could exploit the mobile Safari flaw in order to gain access and cause harm to the Apple [[iPad]]. ==AT&T/iPad e-mail address leak== In June 2010, Goatse Security uncovered a vulnerability within the [[AT&T]] website. AT&T was the only provider of [[3G]] service for Apple's iPad in the [[United States]]. When signing up for AT&T's 3G service from an iPad, AT&T retrieves the [[ICC-ID]] from the iPad's [[SIM card]] and associates it with the Email address provided during sign-up. In order to ease the log-in process from the iPad, the AT&T website receives the SIM card's ICC-ID and pre-populates the Email address field with the address provided during sign-up. Goatse Security realized that by sending a [[HTTP request]] with a valid ICC-ID embedded inside it to the AT&T website, the website would reveal the Email address associated with that ICC-ID. On June 5, 2010, Daniel Spitler, aka "JacksonBrown", began discussing this vulnerability and possible ways to exploit it, including [[phishing]], on an IRC channel. Goatse Security constructed a [[PHP]]-based [[Brute force attack|brute force]] script that would send HTTP requests with random ICC-IDs to the AT&T website until a legitimate ICC-ID is entered, which would return the Email address corresponding to the ICC-ID. This script was dubbed the "iPad 3G Account Slurper." Goatse Security then attempted to find an appropriate news source to confine the leaked information with. weev attempted to contact [[News Corporation]] and [[Thomson Reuters]] executives, including [[Arthur Siskind]], about AT&T's security problems. On June 6, 2010, weev sent Emails with some of the ICC-IDs recovered in order to verify his claims. Chat logs from this period also reveal that attention and publicity may have been incentives for the group. The tactics used by members of Goatse Security caused a significant debate regarding the proper disclosure of IT security flaws.{{cite news |title=Computer Experts Face Backlash |first=Ben |last=Worthen |author2=Spencer E. Ante |newspaper=WSJ.com |date=June 14, 2010 |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703885104575303032919382858.html?mod=WSJ_hpp_sections_tech }} weev has maintained that Goatse Security used common industry standard practices and has said that, "We tried to be the good guys".{{cite news|last=Leydon|first=John|title=AT&T iPad 'hacker' breaks gag order to rant at cops|url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2010/07/07/ipad_hack_follow_up/|accessdate=16 February 2011|newspaper=The Register|date=7 July 2010}} [[Jennifer Granick]] of the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] has also defended the tactics used by Goatse Security. On June 14, 2010 [[Michael Arrington]] of [[TechCrunch]] awarded the group a Crunchie award for public service. This was the first time a Crunchie was awarded outside the annual Crunchies award ceremony.{{cite news|last=Arrington|first=Michael|title=Weâre Awarding Goatse Security A Crunchie Award For Public Service|url=http://techcrunch.com/2010/06/14/were-awarding-goatse-security-a-crunchie-award-for-public-service/|accessdate=31 March 2010|newspaper=Tech Crunch|date=14 June 2010}}{{cite news|last=Patterson|first=Ben|title=AT&T apologizes for iPad breach, blames hackers|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ytech_gadg/20100614/tc_ytech_gadg/ytech_gadg_tc2564|accessdate=31 March 2010|newspaper=Yahoo! News|date=14 June 2010}} The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] then opened an investigation into the incident,{{cite news |first=Ryan |last=Tate |authorlink= |title=Apple's Worst Security Breach: 114,000 iPad Owners Exposed |url=http://gawker.com/5559346/apples-worst-security-breach-114000-ipad-owners-exposed |newspaper=[[Gawker.com]] |publisher=[[Gawker Media]] |date=June 9, 2010 |accessdate=June 13, 2010}} leading to a criminal complaint in January 2011United States District Court - District Court of New Jersey, Docket: MAG 11-4022 (CCC). Filed with the court January 13, 2011 and a raid on [[weev|Andrew Auernheimer's]] house. The search was related to the AT&T investigation and Auernheimer was subsequently detained and released on bail{{cite news |first=Jesse |last= Emspak, |coauthors= |first= Gabriel |last=Perna |title=Arrested Hacker's Web Site Reveals Extremist Views |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/29267/20100617/goatse-hacker-blog-shows-extremist-views.htm |newspaper=[[International Business Times]] |publisher=[[International Business Times]] |date=June 17, 2010 |accessdate=July 11, 2010}} on state drug charges,{{cite news |title=Programmer Detained After FBI Search |first=Andrew |last=Dowell |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |date=June 17, 2010 |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704198004575310634055906968.html?mod=WSJ_PersonalTechnology_LEFTTop }} later dropped.{{cite news |title= Criminal charges filed against AT&T iPad attackers - Computerworld |date=January 18, 2011|url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9205403/Criminal_charges_filed_against_AT_T_iPad_attackers}} After his release on bail, he broke a [[gag order]] to protest and to dispute the legality of the search of his house and denial of access to a [[public defender]]. He also asked for donations via [[PayPal]], to defray legal costs.[http://www.theregister.co.uk/2010/07/07/ipad_hack_follow_up/ AT&T iPad 'hacker' breaks gag order to rant at cops] [[The Register]], John Leyden. July 7, 2010{{cite web|title=Hypocrites and Pharisees|url=http://security.goatse.fr/hypocrites-and-pharisees|publisher=Goatse.fr|author=weev}} In 2011 the Department of Justice announced that he will be charged with one count of conspiracy to access a computer without authorization and one count of fraud. A co-defendant, Daniel Spitler, was released on bail.{{cite news|last=Voigt|first=Kurt|title=No bail for 2nd iPad e-mail address theft suspect|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41196595/ns/technology_and_science-security/|accessdate=15 February 2011|newspaper=MSNBC.com|date=21 January 2011|agency=Associated Press}}{{cite news|last=Porter|first=David|title=Suspect in iPad Data Theft Released on Bail in NJ|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/wireStory?id=13023509|accessdate=2 March 2011|newspaper=ABC News|date=28 February 2011|agency=Associated Press}} As of May, 2011 he remains released on bail. ==References== {{Reflist |1=2 |refs= {{cite news |title=Goatse Security trolls were after "max lols" in AT&T iPad hack |first=Chris |last=Foresman |url=http://arstechnica.com/apple/news/2011/01/goatse-security-trolls-were-after-max-lols-in-att-ipad-hack.ars |newspaper=[[Ars Technica]] |date=2011-01-19 |accessdate=2011-01-22}} {{cite news |title=U.S. Announces Charges for Alleged Hack Into AT&T Servers Via iPad Users |first=David |last=Voreacos |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-18/u-s-to-announce-charges-on-alleged-hack-into-at-t-servers-via-ipad-users.html |newspaper=[[Bloomberg.com]] |date=2011-01-18 |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]] |accessdate=2011-01-21}} {{cite news |title=Hackers say iPad has more security holes |first=David |last=Goldman |newspaper=[[CNNMoney.com]] |date=2010-06-14 |url=http://money.cnn.com/2010/06/14/technology/att_ipad_hack/ |publisher=[[CNN]] |accessdate=2010-09-18}} [http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/102701/20110119/case-against-ipad-hackers.htm Criminal Complaint].
